problems.title: Find Nth Node from End in SLL
problems.description:
Problem Statement
You are given N integers to create a Singly Linked List (SLL) and an integer K. Your task is to find the Kth node from the end of the linked list and print its value. If K is greater than the length of the list, print -1.

Input Format
The first line contains an integer N (size of the list).
The second line contains N space-separated integers.
The third line contains an integer K (position from end).

Output Format
Print the value of the Kth node from the end, or -1 if K > N.

Example
Input:
5
10 20 30 40 50
2
Output: 40
Explanation: The 2nd node from the end has value 40.
problems.constraints:
1 ≤ N ≤ 10^5
1 ≤ K ≤ N
-10^9 ≤ Array elements ≤ 10^9
Time Complexity: O(N)
Space Complexity: O(1)

problems.title: Remove Duplicates from Unsorted SLL
problems.description:
Problem Statement
You are given N integers to create a Singly Linked List (SLL). The list may contain duplicate values. Your task is to remove all duplicate nodes and keep only the first occurrence of each value. Display the resulting list.

Input Format
The first line contains an integer N (size of the list).
The second line contains N space-separated integers.

Output Format
Print the elements of the list after removing duplicates, separated by spaces.

Example
Input:
6
1 2 3 2 4 1
Output: 1 2 3 4
problems.constraints:
1 ≤ N ≤ 10^5
-10^9 ≤ Array elements ≤ 10^9
Time Complexity: O(N)
Space Complexity: O(N)
hintsList: Use a hash set to track seen values while traversing the list and remove nodes with duplicate values.

problems.title: Detect Cycle in SLL
problems.description:
Problem Statement
You are given N integers to create a Singly Linked List (SLL). Additionally, you are given an integer P which indicates that the last node should point to the Pth node (1-based index) to create a cycle. If P is 0 or greater than N, there is no cycle. Your task is to detect if there is a cycle in the linked list. Print YES if a cycle exists, otherwise print NO.

Input Format
The first line contains an integer N (size of the list).
The second line contains N space-separated integers.
The third line contains an integer P (position to create cycle, 0 means no cycle).

Output Format
Print YES or NO.

Example
Input:
4
1 2 3 4
2
Output: YES
Explanation: Last node (4) points to 2nd node, creating a cycle.
problems.constraints:
1 ≤ N ≤ 10^5
0 ≤ P ≤ N
-10^9 ≤ Array elements ≤ 10^9
Time Complexity: O(N)
Space Complexity: O(1)
hintsList: Use Floyd's Cycle Detection Algorithm (slow and fast pointers).

problems.title: Merge Two Sorted Linked Lists
problems.description:
Problem Statement
You are given two sorted Singly Linked Lists. Your task is to merge them into a single sorted linked list and display the elements.

Input Format
The first line contains an integer N1 (size of first list).
The second line contains N1 space-separated sorted integers.
The third line contains an integer N2 (size of second list).
The fourth line contains N2 space-separated sorted integers.

Output Format
Print the elements of the merged sorted list separated by spaces.

Example
Input:
3
1 3 5
3
2 4 6
Output: 1 2 3 4 5 6
problems.constraints:
0 ≤ N1, N2 ≤ 10^5
-10^9 ≤ Array elements ≤ 10^9
Both lists are sorted in ascending order
Time Complexity: O(N1 + N2)
Space Complexity: O(1)

starterCodes.code:
class Node:
    def __init__(self, data):
        self.data = data
        self.next = None

def insertAtEnd(arr, n):
    head = tail = None
    for x in arr:
        newNode = Node(x)
        if head is None:
            head = tail = newNode
        else:
            tail.next = newNode
            tail = newNode
    return head

def mergeSortedLists(head1, head2):
    # TODO: Merge two sorted lists and return the merged head
    return head1

def display(head):
    while head:
        print(head.data, end=" ")
        head = head.next

def solve():
    import sys
    input_data = sys.stdin.read().split()
    if not input_data: return
    idx = 0
    n1 = int(input_data[idx])
    idx += 1
    arr1 = list(map(int, input_data[idx:idx+n1]))
    idx += n1
    n2 = int(input_data[idx])
    idx += 1
    arr2 = list(map(int, input_data[idx:idx+n2]))
    head1 = insertAtEnd(arr1, n1)
    head2 = insertAtEnd(arr2, n2)
    merged = mergeSortedLists(head1, head2)
    display(merged)

if __name__ == '__main__':
    solve()

hintsList: Compare values from both lists and link nodes in sorted order using a dummy node.

problems.title: Rotate Linked List by K positions
problems.description:
Problem Statement
You are given N integers to create a Singly Linked List (SLL) and an integer K. Your task is to rotate the linked list to the right by K positions and display the resulting list.

Input Format
The first line contains an integer N (size of the list).
The second line contains N space-separated integers.
The third line contains an integer K (number of positions to rotate).

Output Format
Print the elements of the rotated list separated by spaces.

Example
Input:
5
1 2 3 4 5
2
Output: 4 5 1 2 3
Explanation: Rotating right by 2: [4,5,1,2,3]
problems.constraints:
1 ≤ N ≤ 10^5
0 ≤ K ≤ 10^9
-10^9 ≤ Array elements ≤ 10^9
Time Complexity: O(N)
Space Complexity: O(1)
